text: hi I'm Liz I wanted to give you a quick
overview of the talk I did today uh
called Epiphany and ephany so Epiphany
is the sense that we get um when we
understand something for the first time
we go oh I get it right apophony was
actually a word it was coined by a
German psychologist called CLA comrad to
uh name that sense of epiphany that
schizophrenics get when they see
something and they go oh get it but
they're actually wrong and it's come
through to English as apophenia which is
a tendency to see patterns that don't
exist so what happens is that we see
something we think we understand it we
fix dat on it and it forms a kind of
confirmation bias and the talk I
actually used elephants if you get to
see it you'll see the elephants I'm just
going to give you a really quick example
now if I do this on the wall with my
hand you can see that and you probably
go oh look it's a deer it's not a deer
it's my hand but you're familiar with
the pattern and because you're familiar
with the pattern you fixate on it the
problem comes when we're dealing with
uncertainty and we're dealing with
patterns we've never encountered before
and we don't know what's going to happen
human beings really really hate
uncertainty and we're not good with
dealing it with it we actually prefer to
have certain outcomes even if the
outcomes are bad it's less stressful to
us than having uncertainty in holding
onto uncertainty so there was an
experiment done by University College
London where they hid snakes under rocks
and people turned over the rocks with
the snakes underneath and if there was a
snake underneath the rock they got an
electric shock the object of this game
was you had to learn how the snake
population behaved and they varied the
probability of the snakes under the
Rocks they've also measured people's
stress levels while they were playing
the game and the people who didn't get
shocked very often they weren't very
stressed but nor were the people who
were getting shocked a lot of the time
they were kind of inured to it the
people who are most stressed were the
ones with a 50% chance of having a snake
under a rock that didn't know whether
they were going to get shocked or not
and there's an awful number of studies
huge number of studies that show not
only do we hate uncertainty we're also
really really bad at dealing with it and
there's a great paper called judgment
under uncertainty so what happens when
we're dealing with something new that
we've never encountered before in
software development we do that all the
time because we're always trying to
solve problems that nobody solved before
I always say you know the third time a
software developer encounters the same
problem they tend to write open source
to solve it and a lot of what we do is
based on devs like me writing stuff on
the internet so that we don't have to
solve the the same problems again or you
get something off the shelf so most of
what we're doing is either learning how
to use new bits of code or writing new
bits of code to solve new
problems because we've never encountered
them before we have no expertise over
them and so we can't analyze the problem
when we have expertise you can close the
gap between what you have and what
you're expecting that's called analysis
but when you're dealing with stuff
that's
emergent you have to do something that's
a little bit more trying things out in a
way that's safe to fail so in the talk I
introduce the canevin framework which
calls those two domains complicated for
stuff that requires expertise and
complex for things which are emergent we
call the practice of trying things out
probing which means try something in a
way that's safe to fail and a good probe
has to have some indicators of success
some indicators of failure a way of
dampening if we find out that it's
failing a way of amplifying it if we
find out that it's succeeding in
coherence which is a realistic reason
for thinking this is a good
idea the problem comes when we start
doing
planning based on our very limited
experience without considering that it's
it's just there for coherence um and we
start doing estimates over things that
we've never done before so we don't know
how long they're going to
take so I talked about analysis
paralysis and these thrashing sessions
where people bring in this problem and
then everybody goes well I think we
could do it this way and other people go
well that won't work because that won't
work because that won't work because and
it's really hard when you've never
encountered it to work out which
scenarios are going to be relevant what
things you really have to consider so I
suggest to all the deaths in the room do
a proof of concept do a spike do
something that's what we call a probe in
software development and the various
different levels of Spike prototype
Alphas betas they're there to help us
work out get feedback and um try things
out in front of different audiences so
we might do a spike to prove to
something is possible for ourselves we
might do a proof of concept to prove to
somebody else that it's possible we'll

users and see what they think once we
start doing Alphas we start getting them
in front of innovators and early
adopters they will usually willing to

us but by the time we're actually

where things start off in Genesis they
start off custombuilt um they're

in complicated domains we have governing
constraints which are rules which have
all always have to
apply um as an example you can think of
trying to get things on the App Store
Apple have a ton of rules they're not
going to flex those rules for for me
just as a Dev right and they apply
regardless of what I do whereas if I'm

as a little prototype maybe we might

but something you can do is listen to
